column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=kind of Sweet meats you like best upon every one, so close them up and
#Text= fry them with Butter, and serve them in with fine Sugar strewed on.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 149.
#Text=_To boil a Capon on the French fashion._
#Text=
#Text= Boil your Capon in water and salt, and a little dusty Oatmeal to make it
#Text= look white, then take two or three Ladles full of Mutton Broth, a Faggot
#Text= of sweet herbs, two or three Dates cut in long pieces, a few parboiled
#Text= Currans, and a little whole Pepper, a little Mace and Nutmeg, thicken
#Text= it with Almonds; season it with Verjuice, Sugar, and a little sweet
#Text= Butter, then take up your Capon and lard it well with preserved Limon,
#Text= then lay it in a deep Dish, and pour the broth upon it; then Garnish
#Text= your Dish with Suckets and preserved Barberries.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 150.
#Text=_To Souce a Pike, Carp or Bream._
#Text=
#Text= Draw your Fish, but scale it not, and save the Liver of it; wash it very
#Text= well, then take white Wine, as much water again as Wine, boil them
#Text=together with whole Spice, Salt and a bundle of sweet Herbs, and when
#Text= boiles put in your Fish, and just before it a little Vinegar; for that
#Text= will make it crisp: when it is enough, take it up and put it into a
#Text= Trey, then put into the Liquor some whole Pepper, and whole Ginger, and
#Text= when it is boiled enough, take it off and cool it, and when it is quite
#Text= cold, put in your Fish, and when you serve it in, lay some of the Jelly
#Text= about the Dish sides, and some Fennel and Sawcers of Vinegar.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 151.
#Text=_To boil a Gurnet on the French fashion._
#Text=
#Text= Draw your Gurnet and wash it, boil it in water and salt and a bundle of
#Text= sweet herbs; when it is enough, take it up and put it into a Dish with
#Text= Sippets over a Chafingdish of Coals; then take Verjuice, Butter, Nutmeg
#Text= and Pepper, and the yolks of two Eggs, heat it together, and pour over
#Text= it; Garnish your Dish as you please.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 152.
#Text=_To rost a Leg of Mutton on the French fashion._
#Text=
#Text=Take a Leg of Mutton, and pare off all the Skin as thin as you can, then
#Text= lard it with sweet Lard, and stick it with Cloves, when it is half
#Text= rosted, cut off three or four thin pieces, and mince it with sweet
#Text= herbs, and a little beaten Ginger, put in a Ladle full of Claret wine,
#Text= and a little sweet butter, two sponfuls of Verjuice and a little Pepper,
#Text= a few Capers, then chop the yolks of two hard Eggs in it, then when
#Text= these have stewed a while in a Dish, put your bonie part which is rosted
#Text= into a Dish, and pour this on it and serve it in.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 153.
#Text=_To rost a Neats tongue._
#Text=
#Text= Chop sweet herbs fine with a piece of raw Apple, season it with Pepper
#Text= and Ginger, and the yolk of an Egg made hard and minced small, then
#Text= stuff your Tongue with this, and rost it well, and baste it with Butter
#Text= and Wine; when it is enough, take Verjuice, Butter, and the Juice of a
#Text= Limon, and a little Nutmeg, then Dish your Tongue and pour this Sauce
#Text= over it and serve it in.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=154.
#Text=_To boil Pigeons with Rice._
#Text=
#Text= Take your Pigeons and truss them, and stuff their bellies with sweet
#Text= herbs, then put them into a Pipkin with as much Mutton broth as will
#Text= cover them, with a blade of Mace and some whole Pepper; boil all these
#Text= together until the Pigeons be tender, and put in Salt:
#Text=
#Text= Then take them from the fire, and scum off the Fat very clean, then put
#Text= in a piece of sweet Butter, season it with Verjuice, Nutmeg and a little
#Text= Sugar, thicken it with Rice boiled in sweet Cream.
#Text=Garnish your Dish
#Text= with preserved Barberries and Skirret Roots boiled tender.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 155.
#Text=_To boil a Rabbit._
#Text=
#Text= Take a large Rabbit, truss it and boil it with a little Mutton Broth,
#Text= white Wine and a blade of Mace, then take Lettuce, Spinage, and Parsley,
#Text= Winter-Savory and sweet Marjoram, pick all these and wash them clean,
#Text= and bruise them a little to make the Broth look green, thicken it with
#Text= the Crust of a Manchet first steeped in a little Broth, and put in a
#Text=little sweet Butter, season it with Verjuice and Pepper, and serve it to
#Text= the Table upon Sippets; Garnish the Dish with Barberries.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 156.
#Text=_To boil a Teal or Wigeon._
#Text=
#Text= Parboil either of these Fowls and throw them into a pail of fair Water,
#Text= for that taketh away the Rankness, then rost them half, and take them
#Text= from the fire, and put sweet herbs in the bellies of them, and stick the
#Text= Brests with Cloaves, then put them in a Pipkin with two or three ladles
#Text= full of Mutton broth, very strong of the Meat, a blade of whole Mace,
#Text= two or three little Onions minced small; thicken it with a Toast of
#Text= Houshold bread, and put in a little Butter, then put in a little
#Text= Verjuice, so take it up and serve it.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 157.
#Text=_To boil Chickens or Pigeons with Goosberries or Grapes._
#Text=
#Text= Boil them with Mutton Broth and white Wine, with a blade of Mace and a
#Text= little Salt, and let their bellies be filled with sweet herbs, when they
#Text=are tender thicken the Broth with a piece of Manchet, and the yolks of
#Text= two hard Eggs, strained with some of the Broth, and put it into a deep
#Text= Dish with some Verjuice and Butter and Sugar, then having Goosberries or
#Text= Grapes tenderly scalded, put them into it, then lay your Chickens or
#Text= Pigeons into a Dish, and pour the Sauce over them, and serve them in.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 158.
#Text=_A made Dish of Rabbits Livers._
#Text=
#Text= Take six Livers and chop them fine with sweet herbs and the yolks of two
#Text= hard Eggs, season it with beaten Spice, and Salt, and put in some
#Text= plumped Currans, and a little melted Butter, so mix them very well
#Text= together, and having some Paste ready rouled thin, make it into little
#Text= Pasties and fry them, strew Sugar over them and serve them.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 159.
#Text=_To make a Florentine with the Brawn of a Capon, or the Kidney of
#Text= Veal._
#Text=
#Text= Mince any of these with sweet Herbs, then put in parboiled Currans, and
#Text=Dates minced small, and a little Orange or Limon Pill which is Candied
#Text= shred small, season it with beaten Spice and Sugar, then take the yolks
#Text= of two hard Eggs and bruise them with a little Cream, a piece of a short
#Text= Cake grated, and Marrow cut in short pieces, mix all these together with
#Text= the forenamed Meat, and put in a little Salt and a little Rosewater, and
#Text= bake it in a Dish in a Puff-Past, and when you serve it strew Sugar over
#Text= it.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 160.
#Text=_A Friday Pie without Fish or Flesh._
#Text=
#Text= Wash a good quantity of green Beets, and pluck out the middle string,
#Text= then chop them small, with two or three ripe Apples well relished,
#Text= season it with Pepper, Salt, and Ginger, then add to it some Currans,
#Text= and having your Pie ready, and Butter in the bottom, put in these herbs,
#Text= and with them a little Sugar, then put Butter on the top, and close and
#Text= bake it, then cut it up, and put in the juice of a Limon and Sugar.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 161.
#Text=_To make Umble Pies._
#Text=
#Text= Boil them very tender, and mince them very small with Beef Suet and
#Text= Marrow then season it with beaten Spice and Salt, Rosewater and Sugar
#Text= and a little Sack, so put it into your Paste with Currans and Dates.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 162.
#Text=_To bake Chickens with Grapes._
#Text=
#Text= Scald your Chickens and truss them, and season them with Pepper, Salt
#Text= and Nutmeg, and having your Pie ready, and Butter laid in the bottom,
#Text= put in your Chickens, and then more butter, and bake them with a thin
#Text= Lid on your Pie, and when it is baked, put in Grapes scalded tender,
#Text= Verjuice, Nutmeg, Butter and Sugar, and the Juice of an Orange; so serve
#Text= it in.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 163.
#Text=_To make a good Quince-Pie._
#Text=
#Text= Take your fairest Quinces and Coddle them until a straw will run through
#Text= them, then core them and pare them, then take their weight in fine
#Text=and Sugar, and garnish it with Bay-leaves.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 166.
#Text=_To bake a Swan._
#Text=
#Text= Scald it and take out the bones, and parboil it, then season it very
#Text= well with Pepper, Salt and Ginger, then lard it, and put it in a deep
#Text= Coffin of Rye Paste with store of Butter, close it and bake it very
#Text= well, and when it is baked, fill up the Vent-hole with melted Butter,
#Text= and so keep it; serve it in as you do the Beef-Pie.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 167.
#Text=_To bake a Turkey or Capon._
#Text=
#Text= Bone the Turkey but not the Capon, parboil them, and stick Cloves on
#Text= their brests, lard them and season them well with Pepper and Salt, and
#Text= put them in a deep Coffin with good store of Butter, and close your Pie,
#Text= and bake it, and soak it very well; when it is baked, fill it up with
#Text= melted Butter, and when it is quite cold, serve it in and eat it with
#Text= Mustard and Sugar: garnish it with Bay Leaves.
#Text=Bone your Goose and parboil it, and season it with Pepper and Salt, and
#Text= lay it into a deep Coffin with good store of Butter top and bottom, then
#Text= bake it very well, and when it is baked, fill up the pie at the
#Text= Vent-hole with melted Butter, and so serve it in with Mustard and Sugar
#Text= and Bay-Leaves.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 171.
#Text=_To make Pancakes so crisp as you may set them upright._
#Text=
#Text= Make a dozen or a score of them in a little Frying-pan, no bigger than a
#Text= Sawcer, then boil them in Lard, and they will look as yellow as Gold,
#Text= and eat very well.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 172.
#Text=_To make blanched Manchet._
#Text=
#Text= Take six Eggs, half a Pint of sweet cream, and a penny Manchet grated,
#Text= one Nutmeg grated, two spoonfuls of Rosewater, and two Ounces of Sugar,
#Text= work it stiff like a Pudding, then fry it in a very little frying-pan,
#Text=throw them into boiling water, and let them boil till they are enough,
#Text= you may also put some green Goosberries into some, and when either of
#Text= these are boiled, cut them open and put in Rosewater Butter and Sugar.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 182.
#Text=_To make_ French _Puffs._
#Text=
#Text= Take Spinage Parsley and Endive, with a little Winter savory, and wash
#Text= them, and mince them very fine; season them with Nutmeg, Ginger and
#Text= Sugar, season them with Eggs, and put in a little Salt, then cut a Limon
#Text= into thin round slices, and upon every slice of Limon lay one spoonful
#Text= of it.
#Text=Then fry them, and serve them in upon some Sippets, and pour over them
#Text= Sack, Sugar and butter.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 183.
#Text=_To make Apple Puffs._
#Text=
#Text= Take a Pomewater, or any other Apple that is not hard or harsh in taste,
#Text=mince it with a few Raisins of the Sun stoned, then wet them with Eggs,
#Text= and beat them together with the back of a Spoon, season them with
#Text= Nutmeg, Rosewater, Sugar, and Ginger, drop them into a frying pan with a
#Text= Spoon into hot Butter, and fry them, then serve them in with the juice
#Text= of an Orange and a little Sugar and Butter.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 184.
#Text=_To make Kickshaws, to bake or fry in what shape you please._
#Text=
#Text= Take some Puff-paste and roul it thin, if you have Moulds work it upon
#Text= them with preserved Pippins, and so close them, and fry or bake them,
#Text= but when you have closed them you must dip them in the yolks of Eggs,
#Text= and that will keep all in; fill some with Goosberries, Rasberries, Curd,
#Text= Marrow, Sweet-breads, Lambs Stones, Kidney of Veal, or any other thing
#Text= what you like best, either of them being seasoned before you put them in
#Text= according to your mind, and when they are baked or fryed, strew Sugar on
#Text= them, and serve them in.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 185.
#Text=_To make an_ Italian _Pudding._
#Text=fry thin slices of Bacon, and lay upon them, and some Samphire washed
#Text= from the Salt, and some slices of Limon; Garnish your Dish with the same
#Text= and serve it in.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 195.
#Text=_To boil Sausages._
#Text=
#Text= Take two pounds of Sausages, and boil them with a quart of Claret Wine
#Text= and a bundle of sweet herbs, and whole Cloves and Mace; then put in a
#Text= little Butter, when they are enough, serve them in with this Liquor and
#Text= some Mustard in Sawcers.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 196.
#Text=_To boil Goose Giblets._
#Text=
#Text= Boil them with water and salt, and a bundle of sweet herbs, Onions and
#Text= whole spice, when they are enough, put in Verjuice and Butter, and some
#Text= Currans plumped, and serve them upon Sippets.
#Text=Thus you may dress Swans Giblets.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 197.
#Text=_To boil Giblets with Roots and good Herbs._
#Text=
#Text= Boil them in a quart of Claret, Ginger and Cloves, and a Faggot of sweet
#Text= herbs, Turneps and Carots sliced, with good store of Spinage and a
#Text= little salt; when they are enough, serve them upon Sippets.
#Text=And add to the Broth some Verjuice and the yolks of Eggs; Garnish your
#Text= Dish with Parsley and pickled Barberries.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 198.
#Text=_To smoor a Neck of Mutton._
#Text=
#Text= Cut your Steaks, and put them into a Dish with some Butter, then take a
#Text= Faggot of sweet herbs and some gross Pepper and a little Salt, and put
#Text= them to them; cover your Dish, and let them stew till they are enough,
#Text= turning them sometimes, then put in a little Claret Wine and Anchovies,
#Text= and serve them upon Sippets.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 204.
#Text=[Transcriber  '  s note: so numbered in original] _To dress Calves
#Text= feet._
#Text=
#Text= Take Calves feet tenderly boiled, and slit them in the middle, then put
#Text= them in a Dish with sweet Butter, Parsley and Onions chopped a little
#Text= Thyme, large Mace, Pepper with a little Wine Vinegar, and a little salt,
#Text= let all these stew together till they are enough, then lay your Calves
#Text= feet in a Dish, and pour the Sauce over them, then strew some raw
#Text= Parsley and hard Eggs chopped together over them with slices of Limon
#Text= and Barberries.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 205.
#Text=_To hash Neats tongues._
#Text=
#Text= Boil them and blanch them, and slice them thin then take Raisins of the
#Text= Sun, large Mace, Dates sliced thin, a few blanched Almonds and Claret
#Text= wine with a little salt; boil all these together with some sweet butter,
#Text= verjuice and sugar; when they are enough, serve them in and thicken the
#Text=that broth into another Pot, with three or four blades of Mace, some
#Text= Currans and Salt, boil them till half be consumed, then put in some
#Text= sweet Butter, and some Capers and a Limon cut like Dice with the Rind
#Text= on, a little Sack, and the yolks of two hard Eggs minced; then lay your
#Text= Mutton into a Dish upon Sippets, and pour this Sauce over it; scrape
#Text= Sugar on the sides of your Dish, and lay on slices of Limon and
#Text= Barberries.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 210.
#Text=_To stew Trouts._
#Text=
#Text= Put two Trouts into a fair dish with some white Wine, sweet butter, and
#Text= a little whole Mace, a little Parsley, Thyme and Savory minced, then put
#Text= in an Anchovy and the yolks of hard Eggs; when your Fish is enough,
#Text= serve it on Sippets, and pour this over it, and garnish your Dish with
#Text= Limon and Barberries, and serve them in: you may add Capers to it if you
#Text= please, and you may do other Fish in this manner.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 211.
#Text=_To boil Eels in Broth to serve with them._
#Text=
#Text= Flay and wash your Eels and cut them in pieces about a handful long,
#Text= then put them into a pot with so much Water as will cover them, a little
#Text= Pepper and Mace, sliced Onions, a little grated bread, and a little
#Text= Yest, a good piece of sweet butter, some Parsley, Winter Savory and
#Text= Thyme shred small; let them boil softly half an hour, and put in some
#Text= Salt, with some Currans; when it is enough, put in Verjuice and more
#Text= Butter, and so serve it; Garnish your Dish with Parsley, Limon and
#Text= Barberries, put Sippets in your Dish.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 212.
#Text=_To boil a Pike with Oysters._
#Text=
#Text= Take a fair Pike and gut it and wash it, and truss it round with the
#Text= tail in the mouth, then take white Wine, Water and Salt, with a bundle
#Text= of sweet herbs, and whole Spice, a little Horse-radish; when it boils,
#Text= tie up your Pike in a Cloth, and put it in, and let it boil till it
#Text= swims, for then it is enough; then take the Rivet of the Pike, and a
#Text= Pint of great Oysters with their Liquor, and some Vinegar, large Mace,
#Text= gross Pepper, then lay your Pike in a Dish with Sippets, and then heat
#Text=216.
#Text=_To make a Steak-Pie._
#Text=
#Text= Cut a Neck of Mutton in steaks, then season it with Pepper and Salt, lay
#Text= your Paste into your Baking Pan, and lay Butter in the bottom, then lay
#Text= in your steaks, and a little large Mace, and cover it with Butter, so
#Text= close it, and bake it; and against it is baked, have in readiness good
#Text= store of boiled Parslie minced fine, and drained from the water, some
#Text= white Wine and some Vinegar, sweet Butter and Sugar, cut open your Pie,
#Text= and put in this Sauce, and shake it well, and serve it to the Table; it
#Text= is not so good cold as hot.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 217.
#Text=_To rost a Haunch or a Shoulder of Venison, or a Chine of Mutton._
#Text=
#Text= Take either of these, and lard it with Lard, and stick it thick with
#Text= Rosemary, then roft it with a quick fire, but do not lay it too near;
#Text= baste it with sweet butter: then take half a Pint of Claret wine, a
#Text= little beaten Cinamon and Ginger, and as much sugar as will sweeten it,
#Text= five or six whole Cloves, a little grated bread, and when it is boiled
#Text= enough, put in a little Sweet butter, a little Vinegar, and a very
#Text=little Salt, when your meat is rosted, serve it in with Sauce, and strew
#Text= salt about your Dish.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 218.
#Text=_To rost a Capon with Oysters and Chesnuts._
#Text=
#Text= Take some boiled Chesnuts, and take off their shells, and take as many
#Text= parboil  '  d Oysters, then spit your Capon, and put these into the belly of
#Text= it, with some sweet Butter, rost it and bast it with sweet Butter, save
#Text= the Gravie, and some of the Chesnuts, and some of the Oysters, then add
#Text= to them half a Pint of Claret Wine, and a pice of sweet Butter and a
#Text= little Pepper, and a little Salt, stew these altogether till the Capon
#Text= be ready, then serve them in with it; Garnish your Dish as you please.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 219.
#Text=_To rost Shoulder or Fillet of Veal with farcing herbs._
#Text=
#Text= Wash your meat and parboil it a little, then take Parsley,
#Text= Winter-savory, and Thyme, of each a little minced small, put to them the
#Text= yolks of three or four hard eggs minced, Nutmeg, Pepper and Currans and
#Text=Salt, add also some Suet minced small; work all these with the yolk of a
#Text= raw Egg, and stuff your Meat with it, but save some, and set it under
#Text= the meat while it doth rost, when your meat is almost rosted enough, put
#Text= to these in the Dish, a quarter of a pint of White Wine Vinegar, and
#Text= some Sugar, when your meat is ready, serve it in with this Sauce, and
#Text= strew on Salt.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 220.
#Text=_To make boiled Sallads._
#Text=
#Text= Boil some Carots very tender, and scrape them to pieces like the Pulp of
#Text= an Apple, season them with Cinamon and Ginger and Sugar, put in Currans,
#Text= a little Vinegar, and a piece of sweet Butter, stew these in a Dish, and
#Text= when they begin to dry put in more Butter and a little Salt, so serve
#Text= them to the Table, thus you may do Lettuce, or Spinage or Beets.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 221.
#Text=_To boil a Shoulder of Veal._
#Text=
#Text= Take a Shoulder of Veal and half boil it in Water and Salt, then slice
#Text=off the most part of it, and save the Gravie; then take that sliced
#Text= meat, and put it in a Pot with some of the Broth that boiled it, a
#Text= little grated Bread, Oister Liquor, Vinegar, Bacon scalded and sliced
#Text= thin, a Pound of Sausages out of their skins, and rolled in the yolks of
#Text= Eggs, large Mace and Nutmeg, let these stew about one hour, than put in
#Text= one Pint of Oisters, some sweet herbs, and a little Salt, stew them
#Text= together, then take the bone of Veal and broil it and Dish it, then add
#Text= to your Liquor a little Butter, and some minced Limon with the Rind, a
#Text= Shelot or two sliced, and pour it over, then lay on it some fryed
#Text= Oysters; Garnish your Dish with Barberries and sliced Limon, and serve
#Text= it in.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 222.
#Text=_To boil a Neck of Mutton._
#Text=
#Text= Boil it in water and salt, then make sauce for it with Samphire and a
#Text= little of the Broth, Verjuice, large Mace, Pepper and Onion, the yolks
#Text= of hard Eggs minced, some sweet herbs and a little salt, let these boil
#Text= together half an hour or more:
#Text=
#Text=then take some of the Broth, a little Mace, and a Cows Udder boiled
#Text= tender and sliced thin, a little Horse-radish root searced, and a few
#Text= sweet herbs; boil all these together, and put in a little Salt, when
#Text= your Venison is ready, dish it, and lay your Cows Udder and the
#Text= Coleflowers over it, then beat up your Sauce, and pour over it; then
#Text= garnish your Dish with Limon and Parsley and Barberries, and so serve
#Text= it; this Sauce is also good with a powdered Goose boiled, but first
#Text= larded.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 225.
#Text=_To make white Broth with Meat or without._
#Text=
#Text= Take a little Mutton broth, and as much of Sack, and boil it with whole
#Text= Spice, sweet herbs, Dates sliced, Currans and a little Salt, when it is
#Text= enough, or very near, strain in some blanched Almonds, then thicken it
#Text= with the yolks of Eggs beaten, and sweeten it with Sugar, and so serve
#Text= it in with thin slices of white Bread:
#Text=
#Text= Garnish with stewed Prunes, and some plumped Raisins.
#Text=mixture following, grated bread, sweet herbs minced small, Beef Suet or
#Text= Marrow minced, Almonds blanched and beated with Rosewater, a little
#Text= Cream; beaten Spice, and a little Salt, some Eggs and some Currans, mix
#Text= these together, and do as I have said, then having your Pie ready raised
#Text= or laid in your baking-pan, put in Butter, and then fill it with Birds.
#Text=Then put in Nutmeg, Pepper and Salt, and put in the yolks of hard Eggs,
#Text= and some sweet herbs minced, then lay in pieces of Marrow, and cover it
#Text= with Butter, and so close it and bake it; then cut it open and wring in
#Text= the Juice of an Orange and some Butter, and serve it.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 247.
#Text=_To make a Lettuce Pie._
#Text=
#Text= Take your Cabbage Lettuce and cut them in halves, wash them and boil
#Text= them in water and salt very green, then drain them from the water, so
#Text= having your Pie in readiness, put in Butter; then put in your boiled
#Text= Lettuce, with some Marrow, Raisins of the Sun stoned, Dates stoned and
#Text= sliced thin, with some large Mace, and Nutmeg sliced, then put in more
#Text=Butter, close it and bake it; then cut it open, and put in Verjuice,
#Text= Butter and Sugar, and so serve it.
#Text=[Transcriber  '  s note: no number in original] _To stew a Neck of Mutton._
#Text=
#Text= Put your Neck of Mutton cut in Steaks into so much Wine and Water as
#Text= will cover it, with some whole Spice, let it stew till it be enough,
#Text= then put in two Anchovies, and a handful of Capers, with a piece of
#Text= sweet Butter shake it very well, and serve it upon Sippets.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 248.
#Text=_To make a Pie of a rosted Kidney of Veal._
#Text=
#Text= Mince the Kidney with the Fat, and put to it some sweet herbs minced
#Text= very small, a quarter of a pound of Dates stoned, and sliced thin and
#Text= minced, season it with beaten Spice, Sugar and Salt, put in half a pound
#Text= of Currans, and some grated bread, mingle all these together very well
#Text= with Verjuice and Eggs, and make them into Balls, so put some Butter
#Text= into your Pie, and then these Balls, then more Butter, so close it and
#Text=Butter, then lay on some large Mace, and some more Butter, and close it
#Text= and bake it: It is either good hot or cold.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 251.
#Text=_To make a Carp Pie._
#Text=
#Text= Take a large Carp and scale him, gut and wash him clean, and dry him
#Text= well, then lay Butter into your Pie, and fill your Carps belly with this
#Text= Pudding; grated bread, sweet herbs, and a little Bacon minced small, the
#Text= yolks of hard Eggs and an Anchovie minced, also a little Marrow, Nutmeg,
#Text= and then put in a little Salt, but a very little, and make some of this
#Text= up in Balls, then Lard the Carp, sew up his Belly, and lay him into
#Text= your Pie, then lay in the Balls of Pudding, with some Oysters, Shrimps
#Text= and Capers, and the yolks of hard Eggs and a little Slices of Bacon,
#Text= then put in large Mace and Butter, so close it and bake it, then cut off
#Text= the Lid, and stick it full of pretty Conceits made in Paste, and serve
#Text= it in hot.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 252.
#Text=_To make an Almond Tart._
#Text=
#Text= Take a Quart of Cream, and when it boils, put in half a pound of sweet
#Text= Almonds blanched and beaten with Rosewater, boil them together till it
#Text= be thick, always stirring it for fear it burn, then when it is cold, put
#Text= in a little raw Cream, the yolks of twelve Eggs, and some beaten Spice,
#Text= some Candied Citron Pill and Eringo Roots sliced, with as much fine
#Text= Sugar as will sweeten it, then fill your Tart and bake it, and stick it
#Text= with Almonds blanched, and some Citron Pill, and strew on some small
#Text= French Comfits of several colours, and garnish your Dish with Almonds
#Text= blanched, and preserved Barberries.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 253.
#Text=_To make a dainty White-Pot._
#Text=
#Text= Take a Manchet cut like Lozenges, and scald it in some Cream, then put
#Text= to it beaten Spice, Eggs, Sugar and a little Salt, then put in Raisins,
#Text= and Dates stoned, and some Marrow; do not bake it too much for fear it
#Text= Whey, then strew on some fine Sugar and serve it in.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=254.
#Text=_To make a Red Deer Pie._
#Text=
#Text= Bone your Venison, and if it be a Side, then skin it, and beat it with
#Text= an Iron Pestle but not too small, then lay it in Claret wine, and
#Text= Vinegar, in some close thing two days and nights if it be Winter, else
#Text= half so long, then drain it and dry it very well, and if lean, lard it
#Text= with fat Bacon as big as your finger, season it very high with all
#Text= manner of Spices and Salt, make your Pie with Rye Flower, round and very
#Text= high, then lay store of Butter in the bottom and Bay Leaves, then lay in
#Text= your Venison with more Bay leaves and Butter; so close it, and make a
#Text= Tunnel in the middle, and bake it as long as you do great Loaves, when
#Text= it is baked, fill it up with melted Butter, and so keep it two or three
#Text= months, serve it in with the Lid off, and Bay Leaves about the Dish; eat
#Text= it with mustard and sugar.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 255.
#Text=_To make a Pie of a Leg of Pork._
#Text=
#Text= Take a Leg of Pork well powdred and stuffed with all manner of good
#Text= Herbs, and Pepper, and boil it very tender, then take off the Skin, and
#Text=stick it with Cloves and Sage Leaves, then put it into your Pie with
#Text= Butter top and bottom, close it and bake it, and eat it cold with
#Text= Mustard and Sugar.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 256.
#Text=_To make a Lamprey Pie._
#Text=
#Text= Take your Lamprey and gut him, and take away the black string in the
#Text= back, wash him very well, and dry him, and season him with Nutmeg,
#Text= Pepper and Salt, then lay him into your Pie in pieces with Butter in the
#Text= bottom, and some Shelots and Bay Leaves and more Butter, so close it and
#Text= bake it, and fill it up with melted Butter, and keep it cold, and serve
#Text= it in with some Mustard and Sugar.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 257.
#Text=_To make a Salmon Pie._
#Text=
#Text= Take a Joll of Salmon raw, and scale it and lay it into your Pie upon
#Text= Butter and Bay leaves, then season it with whole spice and a little
#Text= Salt, then lay on some Shrimps and Oysters with some Anchovies, then
#Text=more Spice and Butter, so close the lid and bake it, but first put in
#Text= some White Wine, serve it hot, then if it wants, put in more Wine and
#Text= Butter.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 258.
#Text=_To make a Pudding of French Barley._
#Text=
#Text= Take French Barley tenderly boiled, then take to one Pint of Barley half
#Text= a Manchet grated, and four Ounces of sweet Almonds blanched and beeten
#Text= with Rosewater, half a Pint of Cream, and eight Eggs with half the
#Text= Whites, season it with Nutmeg, Mace, Sugar and Salt, then put in some
#Text= Fruit, both Raisins and Currans, and some Marrow, mingle these well
#Text= together, and fill Hogs Guts with it.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 259.
#Text=_To make a hasty Pudding in a Bag or Cloth._
#Text=
#Text= Boil a Quart of thick Cream with six spoonfuls of fine Flower, then
#Text= season it with Nutmeg and Salt, then wet a Cloth, and flower it and
#Text= butter it, then boil it, and butter it, and serve it in.
#Text=Take a _Westphalia_ Gammon, and boil it tender with hay in the Kettle,
#Text= then take off the Skin and stick it with Cloves and strew it with
#Text= Pepper, then make your Pie ready, and put it therein with Butter at the
#Text= bottom, then cover your Bacon with Oysters, parboiled in Wine and their
#Text= own Liquor, and put in Balls made of Sausage meat, then put in the
#Text= Liquor of the parboiled Oysters, some whole Spice and Bay Leaves, with
#Text= some Butter, so close it, and bake it and eat it cold, you may put into
#Text= it the yolks of hard Eggs if you please, serve it with Mustard Sugar and
#Text= Bay Leaves.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 271.
#Text=_To bake a Bulloks Cheek to be eaten hot._
#Text=
#Text= Take your Cheek and stuff it very well with Parsley and sweet herbs
#Text= chopped, then put it into a Pot with some Claret wine and a little
#Text= strong Beer, and some whole Spice, and so season it well with Salt to
#Text= your taste, and cover your Pot and bake it, then take it out, and pull
#Text= out the Bones, and serve it upon tosted bread with some of the Liquor.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=272.
#Text=_To bake a Bullocks Cheek to eat cold, as Venison._
#Text=
#Text= Take a Bullocks Cheek, or rather two fair fat Cheeks, and lay them in
#Text= water one night, then take out every bone, and stuff it very well with
#Text= all manner of Spice and Salt, then put it into a Pot, one Cheek clapped
#Text= close together upon the other, then lay it over with Bay Leaves, and put
#Text= in a Quart of Claret Wine, so cover the Pot and bake it with Houshold
#Text= Bread, when you draw it, pour all the Liquor out, and take only the fat
#Text= of it and some melted Butter, and pour in again, serve it cold with
#Text= Mustard and Sugar, and dress it with Bay Leaves, it will eat like
#Text= Venison.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 273.
#Text=_To make a Bacon Froize._
#Text=
#Text= Take eight Eggs well beaten, and a little Cream, and a little Flower,
#Text= and beat them well together to be like other Batter, then fry very thin
#Text= slices of Bacon, and pour some of this over, then fry it, and turn the
#Text= other side, and pour more upon that, so fry it and serve it to the
#Text= Table.
#Text=Take a Peck of fine Flower, and three Pounds of fresh Butter, break your
#Text= Butter into your Flower, and put in one Egg, and make it into a Past
#Text= with so much cold cream as you think fit, but do not mould it too much,
#Text= then roul it pretty thin and broad, almost square, then lay some Butter
#Text= on the bottom, then season your Venison on the fleshy side with Pepper
#Text= grosly beaten, and Salt mixed, then lay your Venison upon your butter
#Text= with the seasoned side downward, and then cut the Venison over with your
#Text= Knife quite cross the Pasty to let the Gravie come out the better in
#Text= baking, then rub some seasoning in those Cuts, and do not lay any else
#Text= because it will make it look ill-favoured and black, then put some paste
#Text= rouled thin about the Meat to keep it in compass, and lay Butter on the
#Text= top, then close it up and bake it very well, but you must trim it up
#Text= with several Fancies made in the same Paste, and make also a Tunnel or
#Text= Vent, and just when you are going to set it into the Oven, put in half a
#Text= Pint of Clarret Wine, that will season your Venison finely, and make it
#Text= shall not look or taste greasie, thus you may bake Mutton if you please.
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= 277.
#Text=_To make a brave Tart of several Sweet Meats._
#Text=
#Text=other Sweet-Meats, tie your Basket about with several sorts of small
#Text= Ribbons: Do not take this for a simple Fancy, for I assure you, it is
#Text= the very same that I taught to a young Gentlewoman to give for a Present
#Text= to a Person of Quality.
#Text=TO THE READER.
#Text=_Courteous Reader,
#Text=
#Text= I Think it not amiss, since I have given you, as I think, a very full
#Text= Direction for all kinds of Food both for Nourishment and Pleasure, that
#Text= I do shew also how to eat them in good order; for there is a Time and
#Text= Season for all things: Besides, there is not anything well done which
#Text= hath not a Rule, I shall therefore give you several Bills of Service for
#Text= Meals according to the Season of the Year, so that you may with ease
#Text= form up a Dinner in your Mind quickly; afterwards I shall speak of
#Text=want, since they have leave to eat and drink: they must wait diligently,
#Text= and at a distance from the Table, not daring to lean on the Chaires for
#Text= soiling them, or shewing Rudeness; for to lean on a Chair when they
#Text= wait, is a particular favour shewn to any superiour Servant, as the
#Text= Chief Gentleman, or the Waiting Woman when she rises from the Table;
#Text= they must not hold the Plates before their mouths to be defiled with
#Text= their Breath, nor touch them on the right side; when the Lord, Master,
#Text= Lady or Mistress shew that favour to drink to any Inferiour, and do
#Text= command them to fill for them to pledge them, it is not modesty for them
#Text= to deny Strangers that favour, as commonly they do, but to fulfill their
#Text= Commands, or else they dishonour the Favour.
#Text=When any Dish is taken off the Table, they must not set it down for Dogs
#Text= to eat, nor eat it themselves by the way, but haste into the Kitchin
#Text= with it to the Cook, that he may see what is to be set away, and what to
#Text= be kept hot for Servants; when all is taken away, and Thanks given, they
#Text= must help the Butler out with those things which belong to him, that he
#Text= may not lose his Dinner.
#Text=They must be careful also to lay the Cloth for themselves, and see that
#Text=shall still go on in imparting what I yet have so fast as I can.
#Text=Now to begin with the Ordering those things named to you:
#Text=
#Text= If it be but a private Dinner or Supper in a Noble House, where they
#Text= have none to honour above themselves, I presume it may be thus:
#Text=
#Text= In Summer time, when the Meat is all taken away, you may present your
#Text= several sorts of Cream Cheeses; One Meal one Dish of Cream of one sort,
#Text= the next of another; one or two Scollop Dishes with several sorts of
#Text= Fruit, which if it be small fruit, as Rasps or Strawberries, they must
#Text= be first washed in Wine in a Dish or Bason, and taken up between two
#Text= Spoons, that you touch them not.
#Text=With them you may serve three or four small Dishes also with
#Text= Sweet-meats, such as are most in season, with Vine Leaves and Flowers
#Text= between the Dishes and the Plates, two wet Sweet-meats, and two dry, two
#Text= of one colour, and two of another, or all of several colours.
#Text=Also a Dish of Jellies of several colours in one Dish, if such be
#Text=required.
#Text=If any be left, you may melt them again, and put them into lesser
#Text= Glasses, and they will be for another time:
#Text=
#Text= If any dry ones be left, they are soon put into the Boxes again.
#Text=If any persons come in the afternoon, if no greater, or so great as the
#Text= Person who entertains them, then you may present one or two Dishes of
#Text= Cream only, and a whipt Sillibub, or other, with about four Dishes of
#Text= Sweet-meats served in, in like manner as at Dinner, with Dishes of
#Text= Fruit, and some kind of Wine of your own making; at Evenings, especially
#Text= on Fasting Days at Night, it is fit to present some pretty kind of
#Text= Creams, contrary from those at Dinner, or instead of them some Possets,
#Text= or other fine Spoon Meats, which may be pleasant to the taste, with
#Text= some wet and dry Sweet-meats, and some of your fine Drinks, what may be
#Text= most pleasing.
#Text=At a Feast, you may present these things following.
#Text=Sweet-meats, the wet Sweet-meats round about and the dry in the middle,
#Text= your wet Sweet-meats must be in little glasses that you may set the more
#Text= on, and between every two glasses another above the first of all, and
#Text= one on the top of them all; you must put of all sorts of dryed
#Text= Sweet-meats in the middle Plate, first your biggest and then your
#Text= lesser, till you can lay no more; then stick them all with Flowers and
#Text= serve them: And in the Bason of Water you send in to wash the Hands or
#Text= Fingers of Noble Persons, you must put in some Orange Flower Water,
#Text= which is very rare and very pleasant.
#Text=In Winter you must alter, as to the season, but serve all in this
#Text= manner; and then dryed Fruits will also be very acceptable; as dryed
#Text= Pears and Pippins, Candied Oranges and Limons, Citrons and Eringoes,
#Text= Blanched Almonds, Prunelles, Figs, Raisins, Pistachoes and Blanched
#Text= Walnuts.
#Text=_FINIS._
